utterances: Yeah, hi.
I went to pretty specialized camps.
I did do a week of the outdoor, campfire, capture-the-flag sort of camp, but for the most part, I went to six-week programs, one in music and then the same science program twice.
And like your guest said, like, I went the first year and I was a counselor the next year.
I don't know if I'm a cultist, but...
Are you the chairman of a major corporation?
I am not.
I do have my own, you know, one-person computer-consulting business, and then I also teach music, private lessons.
So, well, a success story, then.
Ah, yeah, I love the balance of what I do.
It took me awhile to figure out what it was I was going to do, but actually, music camp and science camp helped, though probably in an unexpected way.
I mean, it taught me that those were not things that I wanted to do full time.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So, maybe you didn't enjoy it completely that much.
No, but I think the overall experience was good.

I was telling the screener that because these were dormitory settings, they were good training grounds for going away to college, you know, how to live with a roommate and, you know, take care of your own laundry and, you know, manage your own meals and so forth.
Well, it sounds like you survived the experience, anyway.
Absolutely, yeah.
All right, Tessa.
Thanks very much.
You're welcome.
And let's see if we can get Patrick on the line, and Patrick's calling us from Elkhart, Indiana.
Hi.
Go ahead.
I wanted to comment, I think that your guest is very right on.
I was a very avid camper as a boy.
I went to Boy Scout camp every single summer, looked forward to every day in Boy Scout camp.
I didn't cry when the camp was over because that night, they gave out all the awards, and you got awards.
And then I became a camp counselor, just as he said, and then I sent my boy to camp.
My boy went to space camp.
I sent him to a marine camp down in Florida where he went out on a ship for a week.
And he and I have gone up to the boundary water canoe area for - about a dozen times, and we love the camping.
And I'm a national sales manager for an insurance company.
So, the cultist who became the great success.
Well, I've just - it just hit home, what he said, when he reeled off what the very, very avid campers became successful, became the leaders of our country, and I really believe that.
And I think the Boy Scouts is a fabulous organization.
Well, Patrick, thanks very much for the call.
We appreciate it.
Thank you.
And Tim Noah, there was another interesting category.
Obviously, a lot people did not go to sleep-away camp, and that turns out not to matter.
That's right.
That was the one of my most surprising findings.

I talked to Montana Miller, who's a folklorist, who teaches - or taught, when I wrote this piece - a class called Summer Camp Ethnography at Ohio's Bowling Green State University, and she told me something interesting.

She said that she had done an exercise with her class where she - she had all of her students describe what camp was like for them, and she said, I want you to write this whether you went to camp or not.
And she then collected the papers and read them, and she found it was impossible to tell who the people were who really had gone to camp and who were the people who were making it up.

Because the camp experience is so pervasive in our culture - in movies, in books, in TV stories, in stories you hear from your friends - that people, even people who didn't go to camp, feel like they went to camp, and they've been through this process of psychological sorting, figuring out whether they liked the camp that they didn't go to or didn't like the camp that they didn't go to.
So, I concluded that you are who you camped, even if you never camped.
Timothy Noah, thank you for your time today.
Thank you.
Tim Noah, a senior writer for the online magazine Slate, and joined us from the studio at that magazine.
His article is called ""You Are How You Camped,"" and you're listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
A sad occasion for a reunion; a large New Orleans family scattered by Hurricane Katrina came together this past weekend for a funeral.
It was the first time since Katrina that Chiquita and Selwyn Smith saw dozens of relatives who've relocated across the southeast.
Joshua Levs has followed the story of the Smiths and their three children ever since the storm struck.
And here is his update now on the family's efforts to settle into a new life.
Selwyn Smith's Aunt Melva Rollins was 69 years old.
She had lived in New Orleans her whole life and fled just before Hurricane Katrina; she never made it back alive.
A brain tumor claimed her life last week in McKinney, Texas where she and the Smiths and some of their other relatives had relocated.
Selwyn says more than a hundred family members gathered in New Orleans for the funeral.
Most of the family came together; a lot of people got a chance to, you know, get new numbers --get new telephone numbers and find out.
Pretty much, it was like a homecoming also, too.
You know, bringing everybody together.
He says people shared stories about Aunt Melva but also felt keenly aware of another loss -- the loss of the life that the big, extended family has always shared in New Orleans.
Dealing when somebody's passing is hard already.
And then, you know, even though we're at a funeral and stuff like that, there's a whole lot of stuff on everybody's minds other than what happened.
Stuff like, how to get by and pay the bills where they live now.
Selwyn's relatives have scattered to Texas, Georgia, Florida and other parts of Louisiana.
Selwyn's wife, Chiquita, says it was bittersweet.
Even though it was under those circumstances, it was good to see people and to be around people.
And it felt like, a little normal for a little while.
The kids came, as well.
It was their second trip back to New Orleans.
They first saw the devastation over New Year's.
Fourteen-year-old Kionte(ph) has missed her city terribly.
She said she cried at the funeral and didn't want to go back to Texas.
Hmm.
That always be the hard part because I know I'm going to leave.
But it wasn't so bad this time because like the first time when I actually went to New Orleans, when I left that time I really, you know, that was like really hard.
But this time it wasn't that bad for me.
That's because she's been trying to adjust to life in McKinney and little by little, she's getting there.
Ms.
K.
SMITH: I guess I just said I have to just get used to everything.
Because I know I was going to be here for a while, so I just started having more fun and stuff.
She says she's been spending more time with her friends from her new school.
She also now has her bedroom to herself again.
Kionte's cousin, Trinetta(ph), was living with the Smiths ever since the storm.
The two girls were sharing a bedroom, but at New Year's, Trinetta moved back to New Orleans.
Kionte misses her cousin.
Ms.
K.
SMITH: I've called her everyday, so it's not bad.
